item.title: Qué significa dearth
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 229 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Late Night Cringes Over Trump’s Texting Spree
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel quipped that the president “can do so much damage in one three-day weekend — I don’t know if anybody has ever done more.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Word of the Day: dearth
item.description: This word has appeared in 229 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: La captura de Maduro muestra la nueva estrategia de la CIA en América Latina
item.description: La participación de la CIA en operaciones militares suele permanecer envuelta en el misterio durante años. Pero Trump se ha mostrado inusualmente abierto sobre el trabajo de la agencia en las operaciones de Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager

media:content.media:description: John Ratcliffe, director de la CIA, llegó al cargo prometiendo una renovada atención a la recopilación de información y al reclutamiento de espías.

item.title: Trump’s Politics Are Not America First. They’re Me First.
item.description: Donald Trump is the most un-American president in our history. And in his second term, there is no one to constrain his un-American impulses.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

media:content.media:credit: Ioulex for The New York Times

item.title: Europe Has a Bazooka. Time to Use It.
item.description: For now, Europe’s anti-coercion instrument is less a bazooka than a waterlogged firecracker.
item.dc:creator: Henry J. Farrell

item.title: Taiwan’s $40 Billion Military Spending Plan Stalled by Political Impasse
item.description: Taiwan’s domestic gridlock is revealing a deep-seated fracture over how the island should defend itself and how much it can depend on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

media:content.media:description: President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan inspecting an F-16 fighter jet cockpit during his visit to an air base in Taitung, Taiwan, in 2025. Mr. Lai’s proposal to increase military spending has come under fire from opposition party members.

item.title: Trump Heads to Davos Amid Deep Worries About U.S.-European Alliance
item.description: The gathering of the global elite is set to serve as an all-hands effort to de-escalate tensions between President Trump and America’s allies over his insistence on acquiring Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump leaving the White House on Tuesday night en route to Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 21, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 21, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Trump Mocks Allies in E.U. Before Davos
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 21, 2025.

item.title: Man Gets Life in Prison for Killing Shinzo Abe, Former Leader of Japan
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami, 45, had admitted to shooting Mr. Abe, Japan’s longest-serving prime minister, with a homemade gun at a political rally in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno

media:content.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Shinzo Abe, a former prime minister of Japan, campaigning in Nara in 2022 before he was shot.

item.title: Cuban Immigrant Was Killed in ICE Custody, Family Says in Legal Filing
item.description: The family of Geraldo Lunas Campos said a witness saw him choked by guards in an El Paso detention facility this month. Federal officials said he died by suicide.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Camp East Montana, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention facility in El Paso.

item.title: Another Train Crash in Spain Kills 1 and Injures Dozens
item.description: A train crash in the Catalonia region of Spain killed one person and injured dozens more, officials said. It was the country’s second deadly rail accident this week.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:description: Emergency crews responded on Tuesday after a commuter train derailed when a retaining wall collapsed onto the tracks in Gelida, near Barcelona, Spain.

item.title: Air Force One Turns Back With Trump After Electrical Issue
item.description: The plane was heading for Switzerland when it turned back for Joint Base Andrews. A White House official said there had been a minor electrical issue.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado, Luke Broadwater, Yan Zhuang and Qasim Nauman

media:content.media:description: Air Force One returned to Joint Base Andrews late Tuesday with President Trump on board after experiencing a “minor electrical issue.”

item.title: In Court Record, Official Describes Assault Before ICE Agent Shot Man in Minneapolis
item.description: The agent told an investigator that he was assaulted with a broom and a shovel before he fired a single shot that wounded a Venezuelan man.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:description: Federal agents near the scene where a man was shot by an agent in Minneapolis.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 21, 2026
item.description: Ginny Too and Avery Gee Katz make their collaboration debut in the New York Times Crossword.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

media:content.media:description: This puzzle plays both sides of the fence.

item.title: México responde a la presión de Trump y envía a 37 delincuentes a EE. UU.
item.description: El gobierno de la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum ha intentado mostrar avances en el combate al narcotráfico en un esfuerzo por evitar las medidas con las que amenaza el presidente Trump.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

media:content.media:credit: Meridith Kohut para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Agentes de policía mexicanos en una escena del crimen en Culiacán, territorio del cártel de Sinaloa, en 2024.

item.title: Miami Beach Nightclub Is Condemned for Playing Kanye West’s Song ‘Heil Hitler’
item.description: The club, Vendôme, was hosting several right-wing influencers, including Andrew and Tristan Tate, the brothers who are being investigated in Europe in connection with human trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Isabella Kwai

media:content.media:description: Members of the Tate Brothers entourage were seen giving the Nazi salute at the Vendôme night club in Miami Beach on Saturday.

item.title: House Foreign Affairs Members Call for Machado to Govern Venezuela
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader stressed the need for free elections in her latest bipartisan meeting with lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, on Capitol Hill on Tuesday, meeting with members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

item.title: Pressured by Trump, Mexico Sends 37 Accused Criminals to U.S.
item.description: Mexico has sought to do more to combat its cartels in an effort to stave off airstrikes threatened by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

media:content.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mexican police officers at a crime scene in Culiacán, the home territory of the Sinaloa cartel, in 2024.

item.title: ‘God Is Very Proud’: Trump Marks Anniversary With a Victory Lap
item.description: For roughly one hour 45 minutes, President Trump meandered through his accomplishments and grievances, attacked perceived enemies and threatened allies.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump tossed aside a 31-page list of his accomplishments during a briefing at the White House on Tuesday but still had plenty to say about the first year of his second term.

item.title: Trump Calls Renee Good Killing a ‘Tragedy’ and Says ICE Agents Will Make Mistakes
item.description: The change in tone was stark for the president, who said he had been told that Ms. Good’s father was a strong Trump supporter.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

media:content.media:description: A memorial for Renee Good at the site of her killing.

item.title: ChongLy Scott Thao, Hmong Immigrant and U.S. Citizen, Arrested by ICE
item.description: A Hmong immigrant, who is a U.S. citizen, was released after being questioned for an hour. Federal officials said they had been seeking sex offenders.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

media:content.media:description: ChongLy Scott Thao, a Hmong immigrant and naturalized U.S. citizen, looked out the window of his home as several vehicles with federal agents idled in the street after he was able to return home in St. Paul, Minn.

item.title: Timothy Busfield Ordered Released From Jail Ahead of Sex Abuse Trial
item.description: The “Thirtysomething” star is accused of inappropriately touching a child actor on the set of a TV series. His lawyers have called the allegations “manufactured.”
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Michael Levenson

media:content.media:description: The actor and director Timothy Busfield in 2020. He turned himself into the authorities in Albuquerque last week.

item.title: Another Train Crash in Spain Kills 1 and Hurts 37, Officials Say
item.description: Train service in the Catalonia region will be suspended until it is safe to resume rail traffic, the local operator said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk and Alexandra E. Petri

media:content.media:description: Emergency crews responded on Tuesday after a commuter train derailed when a retaining wall collapsed onto the tracks in Gelida, near Barcelona, Spain.

item.title: On Day 1, Mikie Sherrill Focuses on Utility Costs and Children’s Safety
item.description: The new governor of New Jersey signed six executive orders after taking office on Tuesday. They matched the priorities she campaigned on last year.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully

media:content.media:description: Gov. Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey signed a half dozen executive orders after being sworn in on Tuesday.

item.title: Choque ferroviario en España: un fotógrafo encuentra una nueva pista
item.description: Las autoridades dijeron que encontraron una parte de un tren de la que no se había informado antes. Los expertos indicaron que el hallazgo podría ayudar a esclarecer la causa de la catástrofe, que ha cobrado 42 vidas.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly, Jason Horowitz, José Bautista, Christine Negroni and Roser Toll Pifarré

media:content.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The undercarriage of a train found near the crash site near Adamuz, Spain on Tuesday.

item.title: DOGE Employees Shared Social Security Data, Court Filing Shows
item.description: Employees detailed to the Social Security Administration shared sensitive data through a nonsecure server, the Justice Department disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Social Security Administration does not know what data was shared on the server, the Justice Department said.

item.title: The Buffalo Bills Will Break Your Heart
item.description: My hometown needs a win.
item.dc:creator: Gary Ginsberg

media:content.media:description: Josh Allen runs the ball against the Denver Broncos on Saturday.

item.title: Ex-N.Y.P.D. Officer Cleared of Spying for China Sues Over Firing
item.description: Federal prosecutors quietly dropped their case against the officer, but a Police Department investigation based on the charges led to his firing, the suit says.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar
item.category: Angwang, Baimadajie (New York, NY, Police Officer)

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Baimadajie Angwang said in a new lawsuit that the Police Department tried to give him a “sham investigatory interrogation” that would have involved a hearing in which he would be asked 1,700 questions.

item.title: Georges Borchardt, 97, Dies; Literary Agent Championed Wiesel’s ‘Night’
item.description: Renowned in his field, he counted among his clients five Nobel laureates, including Elie Wiesel, and eight Pulitzer winners as well as the estates of Tennessee Williams and Aldous Huxley.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger

item.title: Carney Speech on U.S. ‘Rupture’ and Canada’s Survival Draws Standing Ovation at Davos
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney got a standing ovation in Davos for starkly describing the end of Pax Americana. He is looking for new allies to help his country survive it.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen

item.title: Naomi Osaka’s Jellyfish Outfit at Australian Open Pushes Tennis Fashion Boundaries
item.description: Arriving to her first match at the Australian Open, Naomi Osaka wore couture designs with athletic wear. Was it a sign of outfits to come?
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk

media:content.media:description: Walking onto the court at the Australian Open, Naomi Osaka looked to some as if she was walking a runway — or down the aisle.

item.title: JD Vance and Second Lady Usha Vance Are Expecting Their 4th Child
item.description: It is the first known time in modern U.S. history that a sitting second lady is expecting a baby while her husband is in office.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and his wife, Usha Vance, at the White House in November.

item.title: Trump Mocks European Leaders Before Meeting With Them
item.description: Also, fewer people are jumping off the Golden Gate Bridge. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Brooklyn Beckham’s Accusations Against His Parents
item.description: On Monday, the eldest Beckham son posted one-sided explosive accusations against his parents on Instagram. His parents have not responded directly.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

media:content.media:description: David and Victoria Beckham, center, with their family.

item.title: Who’s to Blame for Teens’ Social Media Addiction?
item.description: Jonathan Haidt, author of “The Anxious Generation,” returns to the “Hard Fork” podcast to discuss new research about how social media is harming teens and what it’s been like to become the face of a global movement against the platforms.

item.title: Pentagon Hasn’t Yet Been Asked to Plan Greenland Invasion Amid Trump Threats
item.description: Pentagon officials plan for all sorts of military contingencies, but they have not yet been asked to draw up an invasion of Greenland or the aftermath of such an operation.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Nuuk, Greenland, on Tuesday.

item.title: With Greenland, Trumpism Is Doomed Without Restraint
item.description: The president needs counterforces to save him from himself.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; source image by duncan1890/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Escalates Tensions With European Allies With Greenland and Gaza Efforts
item.description: President Trump’s bellicose demands about Greenland and participation in his “board of peace” are deepening worries about the fate of the trans-Atlantic alliance.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs

media:content.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Asked how far he was willing to go to acquire Greenland, President Trump told reporters, “You’ll find out.”

item.title: What Is Your Reaction to President Trump’s Campaign to Seize Greenland?
item.description: The president says he wants the United States to own the semiautonomous Danish territory. European leaders are outraged. What do you think about what is happening?
item.dc:creator: Natalie Proulx

media:content.media:description: Nuuk, the capital of Greenland, in March. Polls show that most of the island’s population does not support being taken over by the United States.

item.description: tktktkt
item.dc:creator: Noriko Hayashi For The New York Times

item.title: Canada’s Leader Warns of ‘Rupture’ in World Order
item.description: At the World Economic Forum, Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada took a stand against President Trump’s desire for the United States to own Greenland, and called on medium-size countries to stand up to larger powers.
item.dc:creator: Amogh Vaz

item.title: C.I.A.’s New Focus on Latin America Reflected in Raid to Seize Maduro
item.description: A senior U.S. official declined to confirm the specific operations in Venezuela, but said a covert team provided real-time support for the military.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager

media:content.media:description: A member of Venezuela’s National Guard at the entrance to the country’s largest military complex in Caracas, the capital, after President Nicolás Maduro’s capture on Jan. 3.

item.title: California Republicans Ask Supreme Court to Block New Congressional Map
item.description: Republicans asked the justices to step in after a federal court rejected their claims that the state’s new congressional map violated the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Laurel Rosenhall

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California speaking in Sacramento in November after voters approved an amendment assenting to the new map.

item.title: How Trump Is Talking Differently in His Second Term
item.description: He’s speaking far more words in public than in 2017, but much less about Obamacare and much more about foreign countries.
item.dc:creator: Jonah Smith
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Some Republicans Begin to Echo Trump’s Case to Acquire Greenland
item.description: While the party remains split as President Trump presses to “take” Greenland, some in his party are publicly embracing his reasoning for wanting to control the territory.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison

media:content.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson spoke to the British Parliament in London on Tuesday, implicitly backing President Trump’s argument that Greenland is vital to U.S. national security.

item.title: Los Angeles School Desegregation Policy Hurts White Students, Lawsuit Says
item.description: Schools with more white children miss out on smaller class sizes and other benefits, the lawsuit says. The policy dates back to desegregation efforts in the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh

media:content.media:credit: Aaron M. Sprecher, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The lawsuit was filed Tuesday by the 1776 Project Foundation, a group that opposes racial preferences in education.

item.title: Photographer Discovers Train Part That Could Hold Key to Spain Train Crash
item.description: Officials said they had located a previously unreported train undercarriage near the site of a deadly train crash in Spain. Experts said the finding could help investigators.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly, Jason Horowitz, José Bautista, Christine Negroni and Roser Toll Pifarré

media:content.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The undercarriage of a train found near the crash site near Adamuz, Spain on Tuesday.

item.title: Cursive Makes a Comeback in New Jersey Schools
item.description: In one of his final acts in office, Gov. Philip D. Murphy signed a bill on Monday requiring third, fourth and fifth graders to learn cursive.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir

media:content.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The cursive requirements in New Jersey take effect immediately and apply to the next full school year.
